Award.AwardTitle: ABI Development: Representation, Visualization, and Modeling of Signaling Pathways in Higher Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University to build the community-based Beacon system to provide computational support for biologists' questions about signaling pathways. Signal transduction pathways hold the key to understanding the early response of higher plants to abiotic stresses, such as drought, flooding, heat, cold, ozone, and salt. For crop plants, the ability to cope with such abiotic stresses can drastically affect productivity. Traditionally, signaling pathways have been difficult to synthesize and impossible to manipulate computationally. Current pathway tools and databases provide only limited support for manipulating pathways as networks. In particular, it is not possible for a biologist to take an existing signaling pathway and ask hypothetical questions that are answered computationally. The project includes the training of recognized authorities by Beacon staff on the system, thereby empowering plant biologists to curate and archive signaling pathways for abiotic stress responses in the Beacon database. Usability of the tool will be addressed via a continual feedback loop between users and developers.

The user interface is an editing environment that represents and manipulates a pathway in a standard graphical notation called SBGN Activity Flow language, built on the network visualization tool VANTED and SBGN-ED, an extension of VANTED. Research herein will extend SBGN-ED to create Beacon. The result will be a curation tool that will allow authorities to enter pathways in SBGN Activity Flow language, edit them, annotate them, and save them to an initial Beacon database. The database representation allows the biologist to impose a semantic, such as Boolean semantics, on a pathway. The Beacon simulation engine is then able to computationally implement those semantics and provide results that can be queried and visualized. The Beacon inference engine provides tools to allow biologist to develop testable hypotheses about pathway components. The Beacon system will interest undergraduate students in computational sciences as well as experimental biologists. Well-established outreach programs at Virginia Tech will be used to provide training and educational outreach activities. An experimental component will be implemented in the final years of the project, where Beacon-based predictions concerning phenotype will be tested in the laboratory. At https://bioinformatics.cs.vt.edu/beacon/, users will have access to project outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"There is ample reason to be concerned in regard to climate change and
crop production. Many regions throughout the world are projected to
experience climate change-induced reductions in crop yields, and
additional challenges are mounting (e.g., pests, water supply, and soil
degradation)." (Rosenzweig et al., 2014)

Responses and accommodations to adverse changes in the environment, such  as drought, salinity, cold, and oxygen availability, are at the heart of
the ability of all plant species to adapt, and, therefore, survive and
flourish. Climate change events are expected to exacerbate the
unpredictability, severity and duration of such adverse environmental
conditions. This has serious consequences for reliable crop production. 
Anticipated global climate change will require directed adaptations of
crop species on an unprecedented scale to sustain agricultural
productivity. A thorough knowledge of the genetic/genomic means by which
plant species adapt to environmental changes is essential for future
efforts to sustain crop yields, and, indeed, to increase them in the
face of a growing human population. The advent of powerful technologies,
which reflect the readout of plant genomes under different conditions,
such as transcriptomics and metabolomics, has made the amassing of large amounts of data from single projects a reality. The prospect of
elucidation of the genetic response networks that regulate plant dynamic
responses to changing environments is becoming closer.  However, our
ability to analyze and synthesize these data has lagged far behind the
application of the high throughput ("omics") technologies. There is,
therefore, an urgent need for more profound analyses of these
increasingly massive, "omics" data sets, and?for the deployment of the
results of such analyses to enrich our current understanding of the
genetic and genomic function of crop plants. From this need for informed
data mining, a new discipline, systems biology, which is a fusion of
computer science with the life sciences, has emerged. The objective of
this NSF-funded, interdisciplinary, Beacon, project was to develop,
employ, and implement the tools of systems biology to uncover, and
understand, those genomic mechanisms in crop plants and trees that
underlie inter- and intra-specific responses to environmental stresses.

A variety of tools already existed to view biological data in the
context of what is already known concerning plant responses to change,
and there was no shortage of databases that provide access to
information regarding these pathways. However, what existed was static,
could not be modified by the user, was often out of date, and any
linking between, and among, components that connected pathways was
haphazard. Plant biologists were often left to use generic graph drawing
software that provided no standardized representation of genomic
function and offered no deeper exploration beyond simple visualization.

Our Beacon system was designed to remedy this deficit by providing the
biologist user with a variety of tools: an interface to draw pathways
using a standardized graphical language, an online repository to store
pathways and (optionally) share them with a community of users, and a
means to make inquiries of, modify, or amend, drawn pathways that have
been stored in the repository. The Beacon tool can be applied to any
data set for any organism for which data are available, even though the
focus of this project was on plant responses to the environment. 
Figures 1 and 2, modified from (Kakumanu et al., 2012) and (Aghamirzaie
et al., 2015) respectively, illustrate applications of the Beacon tool
to "omics" data, one displaying drought-triggered events in developing
maize seeds (Figure 1), and, the other, events that occur during
desiccation of soybean seeds (Figure 2).

The system supports the notion that the visual depiction of pathways is
a powerful tool in the research stages of hypothesis generation and
sense-making, in addition to serving as reference material and as a
teaching tool. It will be possible to populate Beacon images with data
from "omics" experiments, Beacon has the capacity to run simulation, or
"what-if", in silico "experiments", and it is possible to employ Beacon
to infer novel associations among genes that are active in responses to
stress.

(2015) Transcriptome-wide functional characterization reveals novel
relationships among differentially expressed transcripts in developing
soybean embryos. BMC genomics 16: 1.
